enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: - What is the architecture of the Transformer model?
- What are the main components of the encoder in the Transformer model?
- What are the main components of the decoder in the Transformer model?
- How many identical layers are in the encoder and decoder stacks?
- What is the dimension of the outputs produced by the sub-layers and embedding layers?
- What are the two sub-layers in each encoder layer?
- What is the third sub-layer that the decoder inserts?
- How are residual connections and layer normalization employed in the model?
- What is the formula for the output of each sub-layer?
- What is the purpose of modifying the self-attention sub-layer in the decoder stack?
- How does the model ensure that predictions for position i can only depend on known outputs at positions less than i?

SUMMARY: The provided content describes the architecture of the Transformer model, as illustrated in Figure 1. The model consists of an encoder and a decoder, each composed of a stack of N=6 identical layers.

The encoder has two sub-layers in each layer: a multi-head self-attention mechanism and a position-wise fully connected feed-forward network.

The decoder also has these two sub-layers, but inserts a third sub-layer that performs multi-head attention over the output of the encoder stack. The self-attention sub-layer in the decoder is modified with masking to prevent positions from attending to subsequent positions, ensuring that predictions for a position 'i' only depend on outputs at positions less than 'i'. This is combined with the output embeddings being offset by one position.

Both the encoder and decoder employ residual connections around each sub-layer, followed by layer normalization. The output of each sub-layer is defined as LayerNorm(x + Sublayer(x)). To facilitate these residual connections, all sub-layers and embedding layers in the model produce outputs of dimension dmodel = 512.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: Figure 1 shows a diagram of the Transformer model architecture, which is divided into two main parts: the encoder on the left and the decoder on the right.

On the left side, the process begins with "Inputs" which go into an "Input Embedding" layer. This is followed by "Positional Encoding". The result is then fed into a block labeled "Nx", indicating a stack of N layers. Each layer in this stack consists of a "Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer followed by an "Add & Norm" component, and then a "Feed Forward" sub-layer, also followed by an "Add & Norm" component. The output from this stack is then passed to the decoder section.

On the right side, the process starts with "Outputs (shifted right)" which go into an "Output Embedding" layer and then "Positional Encoding". This feeds into another "Nx" block. Each layer in the decoder stack has three main sub-layers. First, a "Masked Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer, followed by "Add & Norm". Second, a "Multi-Head Attention" sub-layer that takes inputs from the encoder stack, also followed by "Add & Norm". Third, a "Feed Forward" sub-layer, followed by "Add & Norm".

The final output from the decoder stack goes through a "Linear" layer and then a "Softmax" layer to produce the "Output Probabilities". The diagram illustrates the use of residual connections, where the input to a sub-layer is added to its output before normalization ("Add & Norm").

Figure 1: The Transformer - model architecture.

wise fully connected feed-forward network. We employ a residual connection [10] around each of the two sub-layers, followed by layer normalization [1]. That is, the output of each sub-layer is LayerNorm(x + Sublayer(x)), where Sublayer(x) is the function implemented by the sub-layer itself. To facilitate these residual connections, all sub-layers in the model, as well as the embedding layers, produce outputs of dimension dmodel = 512.

Decoder: The decoder is also composed of a stack of N = 6 identical layers. In addition to the two sub-layers in each encoder layer, the decoder inserts a third sub-layer, which performs multi-head attention over the output of the encoder stack. Similar to the encoder, we employ residual connections around each of the sub-layers, followed by layer normalization. We also modify the self-attention sub-layer in the decoder stack to prevent positions from attending to subsequent positions. This masking, combined with fact that the output embeddings are offset by one position, ensures that the predictions for position i can depend only on the known outputs at positions less than i.

enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is an attention function?
How is the output of an attention function computed?
What are the components of an attention function, and what form do they take?
How is the weight assigned to each value calculated in an attention function?

SUMMARY: An attention function maps a query and a set of key-value pairs to an output. The query, keys, values, and output are all vectors. The output is a weighted sum of the values, and the weight for each value is determined by a compatibility function between the query and the corresponding key.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS IMAGE***

TABLE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS TABLE***
original_text:
3.2 Attention

An attention function can be described as mapping a query and a set of key-value pairs to an output, where the query, keys, values, and output are all vectors. The output is computed as a weighted sum of the values, where the weight assigned to each value is computed by a compatibility function of the query with the corresponding key.

enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is "Scaled Dot-Product Attention"?
What are the inputs and dimensions for Scaled Dot-Product Attention?
How is the output matrix for Scaled Dot-Product Attention computed?
What is the formula for Attention(Q, K, V)?
What are the two most commonly used attention functions?
What is the difference between dot-product attention and the described algorithm?
Why is dot-product attention more efficient in practice than additive attention?
What happens when dot-product attention is used with large values of dk without scaling?
Why are the dot products scaled by 1 divided by the square root of dk?
What does the Multi-Head Attention architecture consist of?

SUMMARY: The document describes "Scaled Dot-Product Attention". The inputs for this function are queries (Q) and keys (K) of dimension dk, and values (V) of dimension dv. The process involves computing the dot products of the query with all keys, dividing each by the square root of dk, and then applying a softmax function to get the weights on the values. The entire operation is computed on matrices Q, K, and V, with the output matrix calculated by the formula: Attention(Q,K,V) = softmax(QKT / √dk)V. This method is a type of dot-product (multiplicative) attention, distinguished by the scaling factor of 1/√dk. Compared to additive attention, which uses a feed-forward network, dot-product attention is significantly faster and more space-efficient because it can be implemented with highly optimized matrix multiplication. For large values of dk, not scaling the dot products can lead to large magnitudes, pushing the softmax function into regions with extremely small gradients. The scaling factor is introduced to counteract this effect. The accompanying Figure 2 visually represents Scaled Dot-Product Attention and Multi-Head Attention, which is composed of several parallel attention layers.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: Figure 2 features two diagrams. The left diagram illustrates "Scaled Dot-Product Attention", showing a flowchart where inputs Q, K, and V undergo a series of operations. Q and K are first subjected to matrix multiplication (MatMul), followed by a scaling operation, an optional mask, and a SoftMax function. The result is then matrix multiplied with V to produce the output. The right diagram illustrates "Multi-Head Attention", which is depicted as several "Scaled Dot-Product Attention" layers operating in parallel. The inputs V, K, and Q are passed through individual linear layers before entering the parallel attention layers. The outputs from these layers are then concatenated and passed through a final linear layer.

TABLE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS TABLE***
original_text:
3.2.1 Scaled Dot-Product Attention

We call our particular attention "Scaled Dot-Product Attention" (Figure 2). The input consists of queries and keys of dimension dk, and values of dimension dv. We compute the dot products of the

3

Scaled Dot-Product Attention

Multi-Head Attention

Figure 2: (left) Scaled Dot-Product Attention. (right) Multi-Head Attention consists of several attention layers running in parallel.

√

query with all keys, divide each by dk, and apply a softmax function to obtain the weights on the values.

In practice, we compute the attention function on a set of queries simultaneously, packed together into a matrix Q. The keys and values are also packed together into matrices K and V . We compute the matrix of outputs as:

Attention(Q,K,V ) = softmax( QKT √ dk )V (1)

The two most commonly used attention functions are additive attention [2], and dot-product (multi- plicative) attention. Dot-product attention is identical to our algorithm, except for the scaling factor 1√ of . Additive attention computes the compatibility function using a feed-forward network with dk a single hidden layer. While the two are similar in theoretical complexity, dot-product attention is much faster and more space-efﬁcient in practice, since it can be implemented using highly optimized matrix multiplication code.

While for small values of dk the two mechanisms perform similarly, additive attention outperforms dot product attention without scaling for larger values of dk [3]. We suspect that for large values of dk, the dot products grow large in magnitude, pushing the softmax function into regions where it has extremely small gradients 4. To counteract this effect, we scale the dot products by 1√ . dk

ai_summary: The document describes "Scaled Dot-Product Attention". The inputs for this function are queries (Q) and keys (K) of dimension dk, and values (V) of dimension dv. The process involves computing the dot products of the query with all keys, dividing each by the square root of dk, and then applying a softmax function to get the weights on the values. The entire operation is computed on matrices Q, K, and V, with the output matrix calculated by the formula: Attention(Q,K,V) = softmax(QKT / √dk)V. This method is a type of dot-product (multiplicative) attention, distinguished by the scaling factor of 1/√dk. Compared to additive attention, which uses a feed-forward network, dot-product attention is significantly faster and more space-efficient because it can be implemented with highly optimized matrix multiplication. For large values of dk, not scaling the dot products can lead to large magnitudes, pushing the softmax function into regions with extremely small gradients. The scaling factor is introduced to counteract this effect. The accompanying Figure 2 visually represents Scaled Dot-Product Attention and Multi-Head Attention, which is composed of several parallel attention layers.
image_interpretation: Figure 2 features two diagrams. The left diagram illustrates "Scaled Dot-Product Attention", showing a flowchart where inputs Q, K, and V undergo a series of operations. Q and K are first subjected to matrix multiplication (MatMul), followed by a scaling operation, an optional mask, and a SoftMax function. The result is then matrix multiplied with V to produce the output. The right diagram illustrates "Multi-Head Attention", which is depicted as several "Scaled Dot-Product Attention" layers operating in parallel. The inputs V, K, and Q are passed through individual linear layers before entering the parallel attention layers. The outputs from these layers are then concatenated and passed through a final linear layer.

enhanced_content:
QUESTIONS: What is Multi-Head Attention?
How does Multi-Head Attention work?
What are the benefits of Multi-head attention compared to a single attention head?
What are the dimensions of the queries, keys, and values in Multi-Head Attention?
How are the final values calculated in Multi-Head Attention?
Why do the dot products get large?

SUMMARY: Instead of performing a single attention function, Multi-Head Attention linearly projects the queries, keys, and values h times with different, learned linear projections to dk, dk, and dv dimensions. The attention function is then performed in parallel on each of these projected versions, yielding dv-dimensional output values. These outputs are concatenated and projected again to produce the final values. This method allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions, which is an advantage over a single attention head where averaging inhibits this. To illustrate why dot products get large, if the components of q and k are independent random variables with a mean of 0 and a variance of 1, their dot product has a mean of 0 and a variance of dx.

IMAGE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS IMAGE***

TABLE ANALYSIS: ***DO NOT USE THIS TABLE***
original_text:
3.2.2 Multi-Head Attention

Instead of performing a single attention function with dmodel-dimensional keys, values and queries, we found it beneﬁcial to linearly project the queries, keys and values h times with different, learned linear projections to dk, dk and dv dimensions, respectively. On each of these projected versions of queries, keys and values we then perform the attention function in parallel, yielding dv-dimensional output values. These are concatenated and once again projected, resulting in the ﬁnal values, as depicted in Figure 2.

Multi-head attention allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions. With a single attention head, averaging inhibits this.

‘To illustrate why the dot products get large, assume that the components of q and k are independent random variables with mean 0 and variance 1. Then their dot product, g -k = ves, qiki, has mean 0 and variance dx.
